awd_abstract_narration:
Homology is one of the most fundamental and useful invariants of topological spaces and is a measure of the number generalized "holes" in a topological space.  Homology theory has applications in as disparate areas of mathematics as algebraic topology, number theory, mathematical physics, data science, and even economics where it is used to show the existence of Nash equilibria. Homology is useful only to the extent to which one can calculate it. Oftentimes the spaces that one is interested in come in natural infinite families. An interesting phenomenon that simplifies homology calculations for many of these families is homological stability.  Examples of spaces exhibiting homological stability are ubiquitous in group theory, low dimensional topology, algebraic geometry, and number theory. This research project aims to broaden and deepen understanding of homological stability.

This project involves the study of homological stability as well as some generalizations, representation stability, coefficient dependent homological stability, and secondary stability. Representation stability concerns the controlled growth of the homology groups of spaces with group actions. Coefficient dependent homological stability involves studying sequences of spaces where the integral homology does not stabilize but some patterns exist if one works with mod p or p-local coefficients. Secondary stability entails exploring stability patterns in the unstable homology groups of spaces exhibiting various forms of stability. The first two generalizations broaden the class of spaces that fall under the scope of homological stability. In contrast, secondary stability significantly increases the amount of information that one can extract from a sequence of spaces using stability techniques. The investigator will explore these generalizations of homological stability with the goal of proving new stability results for congruence and Torelli-type groups as well as configuration spaces.

Intellectual merit:

Algebraic topology is the study of “holes” in geometric objects called topological spaces. It has diverse applications such as to the Aharonov-Bohm effect in electricity and magnetism and the existence of Nash equilibria in economics. One way of measuring holes is via homology groups, an algebraic object associated to a topological space. Often, the topological spaces of interest come in natural families. For example, for every whole number n, one could study the space of n particles in a 2-dimensional plane. “Homological stability” is a pattern in the homology of a sequence of spaces. Informally, it is the statement that the number of holes of a given dimension in a family of spaces does not depend on which space you look at if you ignore the first few spaces. It is a ubiquitous phenomenon that is conceptually and computationally important for studying homology groups. The purpose of the grant was to study homological stability and its generalizations. These generalizations include:

-Representation stability, a pattern where the homology groups grow but this growth is controlled by symmetries of the space.

-Periodic stability, a pattern where the homology groups are eventually periodic in a stable range.

-Dual stability, a stability pattern in for high dimensional holes.

J. Miller proved many new stability theorems, primarily concerning spaces of interest in geometric group theory and number theory. J. Miller and collaborators introduced new stability patterns such as secondary representation stability. He also resolved several important old conjectures such as a 40-year-old conjecture of Lee-Szczarba, a 30-year-old conjecture of Rognes, and a 20-year-old conjecture of Hatcher-Vogtmann.

Broader impacts: 

The grant supported graduate and postdoctoral training at Purdue by funding research travel and the topology seminar. In particular, it helped graduate students and postdocs make research visits, attend conferences, and bring their collaborators to visit them at Purdue. This was instrumental for networking and skill development. 

Prominent female seminar speakers were encouraged to meet with Purdue’s chapter of the American Women in Mathematics to share their experiences. 

J. Miller participated in Purdue’s Summer Bridge Program which involves faculty mentoring incoming graduate students from underrepresented racial and ethnic groups over the summer before their first year of graduate school. J. Miller worked with a student to learn the basics of algebraic topology and to write a computer program to compute certain topological invariants of spaces coming from number theory. 

J. Miller organized three conferences during the course of the grant. These conferences promoted networking and education.
